<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 304, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 495, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 590, 526]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 527, 606, 543]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 557, 606, 573]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 573, 757, 589]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 590, 440, 605]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 606, 907, 636]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The end \(A\) of a rod \(AB\) of length \(1.2 \mathrm{m}\) is freely pivoted at a fixed point. The rod rotates about \(A\) in a vertical plane. Calculate the angular speed of the rod at an instant when \(B\) has speed \(0.6 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[898, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 138, 92, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 148, 625, 314]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 332, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circular object formed from a uniform semicircular lamina of weight \(11 \mathrm{N}\) and a uniform semicircular arc of weight \(9 \mathrm{N}\). The lamina and the arc both have centre \(O\) and radius \(0.7 \mathrm{m}\) and are joined at the ends of their common diameter \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 396, 153, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 395, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
Show that the distance of the centre of mass of the object from \(O\) is \(0.0371 \mathrm{m}\), correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 413, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 441, 561, 460]]<|/det|>
The object hangs in equilibrium, freely suspended at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 473, 151, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 472, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
Find the angle between \(AB\) and the vertical and state whether the lowest point of the object is on the lamina or on the arc.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 535, 92, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 543, 504, 636]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 567, 811, 631]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 644, 410, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[705, 644, 756, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 682, 920, 749]]<|/det|>
A small sphere \(S\) of mass \(m \mathrm{kg}\) is moving inside a smooth hollow bowl whose axis is vertical and whose sloping side is inclined at \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. \(S\) moves with constant speed in a horizontal circle of radius \(0.6 \mathrm{m}\) (see Fig. 1). \(S\) is in contact with both the plane base and the sloping side of the bowl (see Fig. 2).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 761, 153, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 761, 920, 795]]<|/det|>
Given that the magnitudes of the forces exerted on \(S\) by the base and sloping side of the bowl are equal, calculate the speed of \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 780, 920, 797]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 808, 153, 826]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 807, 920, 841]]<|/det|>
Given instead that \(S\) is on the point of losing contact with one of the surfaces, find the angular speed of \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 823, 920, 841]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
A light elastic string has natural length \(2.4 \mathrm{~m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(21 \mathrm{~N}\). A particle \(P\) of mass \(m \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to the mid-point of the string. The ends of the string are attached to fixed points \(A\) and \(B\) which are \(2.4 \mathrm{~m}\) apart at the same horizontal level. \(P\) is projected vertically upwards with velocity \(12 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) from the mid-point of \(AB\). In the subsequent motion \(P\) is at instantaneous rest at a point \(1.6 \mathrm{~m}\) above \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 168, 223, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 168, 223, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>Find</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[223, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<form>(ii) Calculate the acceleration of \(P\) when it first passes through a point \(0.5 \mathrm{~m}\) below \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 245, 92, 263]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.4 \mathrm{~kg}\) is released from rest at the top of a smooth plane inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The motion of \(P\) down the slope is opposed by a force of magnitude \(0.6x \mathrm{~N}\), where \(x \mathrm{~m}\) is the distance \(P\) has travelled down the slope. \(P\) comes to rest before reaching the foot of the slope. Calculate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 317, 153, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 317, 490, 335]]<|/det|>
the greatest speed of \(P\) during its motion,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 317, 920, 335]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 342, 151, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 342, 517, 359]]<|/det|>
the distance travelled by \(P\) during its motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 342, 920, 359]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 388, 96, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 395, 695, 644]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 662, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the cross-section \(OABCDE\) through the centre of mass of a uniform prism. The interior angles of the cross-section at \(O, A, C, D\) and \(E\) are all right angles. \(OA = 0.4 \mathrm{~m}, AB = 0.5 \mathrm{~m}\) and \(BC = CD = 1 \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 725, 153, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 725, 690, 744]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance of the centre of mass of the prism from \(OE\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 726, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 756, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
The weight of the prism is \(120 \mathrm{~N}\). A force of magnitude \(F \mathrm{~N}\) acting along \(DE\) holds the prism in equilibrium when \(OA\) rests on a rough horizontal surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 803, 153, 820]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 803, 447, 820]]<|/det|>
Find the set of possible values of \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 803, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 864, 670, 882]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Question 7 is printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A small ball \(B\) is projected with speed \(15 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(41^{\circ}\) above the horizontal from a point \(O\) which is \(1.6 \mathrm{~m}\) above horizontal ground. At time \(t\) s after projection the horizontal and vertically upward displacements of \(B\) from \(O\) are \(x \mathrm{~m}\) and \(y \mathrm{~m}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 134, 848, 153]]<|/det|>
Express \(x\) and \(y\) in terms of \(t\) and hence show that the equation of the trajectory of \(B\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 161, 591, 180]]<|/det|>
\[y = 0.869x - 0.0390x^2,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 187, 611, 206]]<|/det|>
where the coefficients are correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 189, 920, 207]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 219, 920, 252]]<|/det|>
A vertical fence is \(1.5 \mathrm{~m}\) from \(O\) and perpendicular to the plane in which \(B\) moves. \(B\) just passes over the fence and subsequently strikes the ground at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 268, 151, 285]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 266, 720, 285]]<|/det|>
Calculate the height of the fence, and the distance from the fence to \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 268, 920, 285]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
